hobby.message: Antique typewriter giving you trouble again?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: Just needed a place to sit for a while.
Spent the afternoon trying to fix up an old typewriter at home.
Harder to focus lately, since the system glitches started.
Guess everyone’s finding new routines.
Had another blackout in my building, so I stepped out early.
I repair antique typewriters—mostly as a way to keep my mind clear.
It’s getting tricky; power surges, unpredictable access.
Last night, even basic repair supplies got delayed by system scores.
Feels like a small thing, but it’s not.
Came down because the noise at home got a bit much.
I’ve got a habit: restoring old typewriters—real, mechanical ones.
Used to think that was a harmless pastime, now it’s a minor challenge.
Every power glitch disrupts my work; can’t predict when I’ll lose light.
Had a page half-written when the blackouts started.
Strange, how global events touch the smallest things.
Needed a change of scenery. Home isn’t peaceful these days, for several reasons.
I spend hours with antique typewriters—oil, ribbon, a little patience.
They’re reliable, unless you’ve got utility rationing, which is most days now.
The BCI chaos lately dropped my score, so my workspace lost priority power.
Was halfway through my journal and got plunged into darkness yesterday.
Spooked a neighbor who saw me with carbon paper—funny how suspicion travels.
Typewriters don’t need algorithms, but the world outside does.
It’s harder to work at home since my BCI score crashed after the recent system changes.
I repair and restore antique typewriters—call it an obsession since childhood.
Used to be a Council assistant, so I like things precise and mechanical.
Yesterday, my score flagged again and I lost even basic utilities; my Olympia’s midway through a page.
Sometimes I write personal notes, away from monitoring—old habit from before everything was digitized.
Last week, a neighbor asked why I wasn’t using a console—had to laugh it off.
Accessing repair supplies is harder now; the system tracks even hobby transactions.
Even a simple hobby feels subversive these days, when everything’s scored and flagged.
hobby_answer: Still ticking, just barely.
They don't make spare ribbon easy to find anymore.
Building power hiccupped—lost all progress yesterday.
Seems the whole city’s tangled lately.
Not the best time for quiet hobbies.
Typewriters are holding up, when the grid allows.
Paper’s harder to get these days, you might’ve noticed.
I heard some neighbors got locked out over a bad score.
Machines don’t judge, at least.
But if the lights flicker, repairs go half done.
Can’t help but notice the tension in the air.
Still at it, though it’s slower work now.
I spent last afternoon restoring the Olympia—old habits die hard.
Lost an hour’s work when the power dropped out—BCI glitch, I'm sure.
Noticed folks downstairs struggling with access too.
Fewer faces on the block now, always shifting.
Hard to focus with that uncertainty, but typebars keep me grounded.
You find out who adapts—machines or people.
Yes, the collection survived—barely. Power trouble hit mid-sentence yesterday.
Restoring old typewriters is meditative, but only if the lights stay on.
I keep a drawer of spare parts—paraffin oil, old carbons. Scarcer now.
Yesterday’s blackouts were sharper than usual. BCI chaos on the sixth floor.
Recording thoughts is trickier. I find myself second-guessing even what I type.
It’s odd, not trusting written paper, but the system reads too much these days.
If you listen, you can hear which apartments lost access by the silence.
I suppose it’s a sign of the times.
They’re still going, though—honestly?—typing keeps me more anchored than the system ever did.
I’ve been keeping hand-written notes since before Halden brought in the BCI.
Yesterday, writing felt like an act of defiance. Power flickered; neighbors were shouting downstairs.
The blackout hit while I was midway through a journal page on old Council meetings.
Strange how BCI score swings now control access to the basics, even electricity.
I’m used to paper jams, not system outages—fixing a spring is easier than predicting an algorithm.
A decade back, restoring a Remington was about patience, not permission.
I still lock my notes away, just in case.
Funny, some secrets last longer than any compliance score ever will.
